questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with a gradual decrease in vision and glare . A slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral, linear, branching, and refractile lines in the cornea, as shown in the image below. The condition is associated with recurrent corneal erosions and may lead to corneal scarring. This presentation is characteristic of?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Lattice dystroph

Stromal Dystrophies

Features

Granular
  • Decrease visual acuity is a feature.
  • Hyaline deposit in stroma
  • Sugar granules with clear cornea in between
  • Stain: Masson Trichrome stain

2 Types:

  • Type 1 (classic)
  • Type 2 (Avellino dystrophy): hyaline + amyloid deposits
  • Combined granular and lattice dystrophy

Macular
  • Least common dystrophy
  • Mucopolysaccharide depositions/GAG deposition.
  • Space between opacities is Cloudy cornea.
  • Autosomal recessive (MC in ICELAND)
  • Gene responsible is CHST6
  • Stain - Alcian blue or Colloidal iron

Lattice
  • Type 1 - classic form, most common stromal dystrophy.
  • Type 2 - gelsolin form, associated with systemic amyloidosis
  • Stain-Congo red stain

Schnyder crystalline dystrophy
  • Associated with disorders of lipid metabolism.
  • Deposits of cholesterol and phospholipids seen in stroma.
  • Stain - Oil red O stain

questions.text: What term best describes the phenomenon exhibited by a 35- year-old male who while speaking, switches topics abruptly and displays continuous speech flow with no pauses or breaks?
questions.explanation:
Term Definition
Derailment Also known as loosening of associations, where ideas slip off track onto unrelated tangents. Unlike flight of ideas, connections are not logical or understandable.
Thought blocking A sudden interruption in speech or thought, where the patient abruptly stops speaking, often reporting a “blank mind.” Seen in schizophrenia.
Neologism The creation of new, meaningless words that are not part of any recognized language. Common in schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with intermittent dysphagia and a sensation of a mass in her chest while swallowing. A barium swallow study is performed and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B: L

Esophageal leiomyoma

Location

Typically arises from the muscular layer of the esophagus

Histology

Composed of smooth muscle cells

Clinical Symptoms

Often asymptomatic, but can cause dysphagia or chest pain

Radiological Findings

Well-defined, smooth, intramural mass on imaging studies calcification can be seen

Barium Swallow

Smooth, symmetrical filling defect, possible luminal distortion

Endoscopic Appearance

Submucosal mass with intact overlying mucosa

Treatment

Surgical resection may be considered based on symptoms and size

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with advanced pancreatic cancer complained of chest pain for 30 minutes . ECG shows inferior wall myocardial infarction. Appropriate measures are taken, but the patient does not survive. Autopsy reveals sterile non-destructive vegetations along the mitral leaflet edges . Which of the following has a similar pathogenesis to this patient's vegetation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Trousseau

Nonbacterial Thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) 
  • Stronger evidence of emboli
  • Associated with malignancy
    • Solid metastatic tumors; adenoma lung, pancreatic, gastric and unknown origin (hypercoagulable)
    • MDS, sepsis, burns
    • Marantikos=wasting away (Greek)
  • Platelets and fibrin (these are clots)
  • Atrial side of MV, ventricular side of AV
  • Looks like infectious vegetation
    • More like thickening

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of intermittent abdominal pain , rectal bleeding, and diarrhea . On colonoscopy, multiple polyps are identified in the colon and rectum . questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with redness, pain, and mucopurulent discharge in the left eye . On examination, chemosis, and branched inflamed blood vessels are observed as seen in the image below. Which organism is the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 

Most common causative organisms
  • Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae

Clinical features
  • Redness, pain, photophobia, purulent or mucopurulent discharge, etc.

Treatment
  • Antibiotics
  • Fluoroquinolones: Examples include ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin.
  • Aminoglycosides: Gentamicin and tobramycin are examples.
  • Macrolides: Erythromycin is a commonly used macrolide.

Investigation
  • Microbiologically (staining and culture) is the primary step,
  • PCR: to differentiate from viral infection if dx is inconclusive.
  • Biopsy

Clinical Signs
  • Congestion in palpebral conjunctiva
  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Chemosis
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage

Additional Information
  • Gonorrhea is the most dangerous infection in children.
  • Erythromycin or silver nitrate ointment in neonates for prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum due to gonorrhoea.
  • If there is systemic involvement, start 3rd generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: A 45-year-old individual is experiencing difficulty sleeping well at night. He frequently wakes up in the middle of the night and has trouble falling back asleep. Additionally, he feels tired and unrefreshed upon waking. There is no significant medical or psychiatric history. What type of insomnia is likely affecting this individual?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B: Middle I

Dyssomnia

Characteristics

Treatment

Insomnia

 

 

 

 

 
  • Difficulty in sleeping
  • Abnormalities:
  • Initial Insomnia: Difficulty falling asleep
  • Middle Insomnia: Difficulty maintaining sleep
  • Late Insomnia: Early morning awakening
  • Non-restorative sleep due to poor sleep quality
  • Pharmacotherapy (e.g., Benzodiazepines like zolpidem and zaleplon)
  • Psychotherapy (Cognitive Behaviour Therapy)
  • Behavioral techniques (Universal Sleep Hygiene)

 

 

Hypersomnia
  • Excessive sleepiness or prolonged sleep
  • Treat underlying cause (e.g., psychiatric)

questions.text: Match the following: 1 A Weber’s test 2 B Bing’s test 3 C Gelles test 4 D Rinne test
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C- 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C:

1

D

Rinne test

2

A

Weber test

3

B

Bing’s test

4

C

Gelles test

Tuning fork test

Procedure

Result

Rinne test
  • The vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid bone and the patient is asked to inform when he/she stops hearing.
  • When the sound is stopped the tuning fork is moved from the mastoid and will be positioned near pinna to test for air conduction pathway.
  • The patient will once again start hearing sounds and the air conduction will go on longer than bone conduction.
  • Rinne (+ve): No hearing loss
  • Air conduction (AC) > Bone conduction (BC)
  • Rinne (-ve): AC < BC Conductive hearing loss or possibly false negative Rinne (seen in severe unilateral sensory neural hearing loss)

Weber test
  • Tuning fork is placed on the top of the patient's head.
  • Sound localization observed.

 
  • Conductive Hearing Loss: Sound shifts toward the affected ear.
  • Sensory Neural Hearing Loss: Sound shifts toward the normal ear.

Absolute bone conduction test

Pre-requisites:

  • Examiner's normal hearing.
  • Air conduction pathway occluded for the patient.

Process:

  • The vibrating tuning fork will be placed on the mastoid of the patient.
  • The patient will be instructed to hand raise when he/she stops hearing the sound.
    • When the patients stop hearing the sound, the examiner will check whether they hear the sound or not for the same duration. If they do means the person has normal bone conduction.
  • Normal Bone Conduction: The patient hears sound for the same duration as the examiner.
  • If the patient's bone conduction is shorter, sensory neural pathway issues may be present.
  • Conductive pathway problems cannot be assessed.

 

 

 

 

Bing’s test
  • The vibrating tuning is placed on the mastoid and alternately open and close the tragus to check whether the patient can hear the sound or not.
  • Normally, when the tragus is closed the patient should be able to hear the sound louder and when the tragus is open the patient should be able to hear the sound softer.
  • Bing (+ve): Normal or sensorineural hearing (Patient appreciates louder sound when tragus is closed, softer when open) loss.
  • Bing (-ve): Conductive hearing loss.

Gelles test
  • Siegle's pneumatic speculum is used to alter air pressure in the external canal.
  • A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid.

 
  • Gelles (+ve): Normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Gelles (-ve): Conductive hearing loss, especially ossicular fixation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of scalp itching. He reports that many of his classmates are experiencing similar symptoms. On examination, gray scaly lesions are observed on the scalp, along with broken hair. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- Tinea

Tinea Capitis

Causative Agents

  • Dermatophyte fungi, commonly Trichophyton tonsurans, Microsporum spp.

Affected Population

  • Common in children, but can affect individuals of all ages.

Clinical Presentation

Scalp infection with various manifestations:

  • Gray Patch Type: Circular, scaly lesions, often with hair breakage.
  • Black Dot Type: Hair shafts with black dots, representing broken hairs.
  • Kerion Type: Pustules, nodules, and boggy swelling; may lead to scarring.

Contagiousness

Highly contagious, especially in the sharing of combs, hats, or personal items.

Diagnostic Tests

  • Wood's lamp examination may reveal fluorescence in some cases.
  • Microscopic examination of infected hairs with KOH preparation.
  • Culture of infected hairs for definitive identification.

Differential Diagnosis

  • Seborrheic dermatitis, psoriasis, and other scalp infections.

Treatment

  • Oral antifungal medications (griseofulvin, terbinafine, fluconazole).
  • Topical antifungal shampoos (ketoconazole, selenium sulfide).
  • Addressing environmental factors to prevent re-infection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the difference between typical and atypical antipsychotics in the treatment of schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Atypical antipsychotics are associated with a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms compared to typical antipsychotics.

options.label: C
options.text: Typical antipsychotics are more likely to cause metabolic side effects such as weight gain, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia than atypical antipsychotics.

options.label: D
options.text: Atypical antipsychotics primarily antagonize D 2 receptors, while typical antipsychotics antagonize both D 2 and 5HT 2A receptors.

questions.correct_answer: A. Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.

Feature

Atypical Antipsychotics

Typical Antipsychotics (First Generation)

Primary Mechanism of Action

Block dopamine (D2) and serotonin (5HT2A) receptors.

Mainly block dopamine (D2) receptors.

Targeted Symptoms

Effective against both positive and negative symptoms.

Primarily target positive symptoms.

Risk of Extrapyramidal Symptoms

Lower risk compared to typical antipsychotics.

Higher risk, especially at higher doses.

Metabolic Side Effects

Associated with weight gain, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.

Lower risk of metabolic side effects.

Sedation

Varies among individual medications; some can be sedating.

Tend to be more sedating.

Prolactin Elevation

Generally lower risk of causing hyperprolactinemia.

Higher risk; can lead to elevated prolactin levels.

Anticholinergic Effects

Generally lower risk of causing anticholinergic effects.

Higher risk, leading to side effects like dry mouth.

Serotonin Syndrome Risk

Lower risk due to the dual receptor antagonism.

Generally lower risk unless combined with serotonergic agents.

Examples

Clozapine, Olanzapine, Risperidone, Quetiapine, Aripiprazole

Haloperidol, Chlorpromazine, Fluphenazine, Thioridazine

Which of the following antibiotics inhibits the attachment of transfer RNA (tRNA) amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- T

Inhibit attachment

  • Tetracycline, Tigecycline
  • Block A-site on 30s Ribosomes
  • Inhibits tRNA AA attachment to A-site

Inhibit translocation

 
  • Macrolides: Erythromycin, Azithromycin
  • Clindamycin
  • Streptogramin: Quinpristine + Dalfopristin (30:70)

Inhibit peptide bond

  • Inhibits Peptidyl transferase by attaching on 50s ribosome
  • Chloramphenicol

Inhibit initiation of protein synthesis

 
  • Linezolid
  • Attaches to 23s subunit present on the 50s ribosome
  • Inhibits attachment of Methionine tRNA (Methininie is the first AA to initiate protein synthesis)

Multiple mechanisms

 
  • Aminoglycoside
  • Binds to 30s
  • Inhibits initiation of protein synthesis
  • Misreading of mRNA- Defective AA attaches
  • Inhibit polysome formation (Attachment of ribosomes on mRNA)

questions.text: The following are various bone deformities associated with rheumatoid arthritis . Match them accordingly. 1) Swan neck deformity a) 2) Buttonhole deformity b) 3) Hitchhiker’s deformity c) 4) Z deformity d) 5) Windswept deformity e) 6) La main en lorgnette deformity f)
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-f, 3-e, 4-b, 5-a, 6

Hitchhiker’s deformity (thumb is involved).

  • Hitchhiker thumb deformity is a musculoskeletal manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis presenting in the thumb, with the combination of flexion of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint and hyperextension of the interphalangeal (IP) joint

La-Main-En-Lorgnette deformity (telescoping fingers)

  • Subluxation of PIP
  • Finger will go down and up like a telescope.

 

Boutonniere/ buttonhole deformity (proximal interphalangeal).

  • Boutonniere deformity is a deformity of the fingers in which the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) is flexed and the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) is hyperextended.

Swan neck deformity (distal phalanx)

  • It is characterized by proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint hyperextension and flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.

Windswept deformity

  • One side knee joint  shows Genu valgum.
  • Other side knee joint shows Genu varum.

Z-deformity (hand)

  • Ulnar deviation of MCP with radial deviation of PIP

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with a history of recurrent, unilateral nasal obstruction and episodes of profuse epistaxis over the past several months. On examination, the following is observed: What sign is likely to be seen on this patient's CECT scan due to erosion of the wedge of the pterygoid?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Chopstick sig

Role of Plain X-ray/CT scan
  • Holmann Miller sign: Anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  • Hondusa's sign: increase in distance between maxillary sinus and mandible on CTscan.
  • Opacification of sphenoid sinus.

Role of CECT scan
  • CTdiagnosis is based on two constant features:

i. Mass in the nose and pterygopalatine fossa.

ii. Erosion of bone behind the sphenopalatine foramen at the root of the pterygoid plate.

  • When the wedge of pterygoid is eroded so the medial and lateral pterygoid plate look like a separate plate, that is called Chopstick sign.

Role of MRI
  • MRI accesses the relation of the tumor to the critical structures such as the internal carotid artery, cavernous sinus and pituitary gland.
  • Recurrent and residual tumors are the best appreciated on the MRI
